bug.short_desc: "Startup extension failed" error when ECF is not available

long_desc.thetext:
The errors below are logged on startup and shutdown when ECF is not available and a Hudson server is configured.
-- Error Details -- Date: Thu Mar 01 22:41:53 CET 2012 Message: Startup extension failed Severity: Error Product: Eclipse SDK 3.7.2.v201202080800 (org.eclipse.sdk.ide) Plugin: org.eclipse.mylyn.builds.ui Session Data: eclipse.buildId=M20120208-0800 java.version=1.6.0_20 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_CA
Exception Stack Trace: org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Plug-in "org.eclipse.mylyn.hudson.ui" was unable to instantiate class "org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.hudson.ui.HudsonDiscovery". at The (expected) exception is now caught and a warning is logged instead of an error.

Hi Steffen,
Can you explain more on what causes the (expected) exception? I saw following exception logged, I guess I am missing a specific ECF plugin in my installation?
!ENTRY org.eclipse.mylyn.hudson.ui 2 0 2013-03-06 14:19:04.497 !MESSAGE ECF integration failed to load. Hudson server auto discovery is not available. !STACK 0 java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/eclipse/ecf/discovery/IServiceListener at org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.hudson.ui.HudsonStartup.lazyStartup(HudsonStartup.java:42) at org.eclipse.mylyn.internal.builds.ui.BuildsUiPlugin$UiStartupExtensionPointReader$1.run(BuildsUiPlugin.java:159) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:42)

The Hudson connector uses plugins provided by the ECF project to automatically discover servers on the local network. If these are not installed and hence class loading fails the auto discovery mechanism doesn't work and the warning is logged.

Thanks, I am trying to find out which plugins are missing from my installation: I do have several ECF plugins already installed: org.eclipse.ecf, org.eclipse.ecf.filetransfer, org.eclipse.ecf.identity, org.eclipse.ecf.ssl, and org.eclipse.ecf.provider.*.
Do I need more than these?

The Hudson UI bundle declares the following depenencies on ECF:
org.eclipse.ecf;bundle-version="3.0.0";resolution:=optional, org.eclipse.ecf.discovery;bundle-version="3.0.0";resolution:=optional, org.eclipse.ecf.provider.discovery;bundle-version="2.0.0";resolution:=optional, org.eclipse.ecf.provider.jmdns;bundle-version="3.0.0";resolution:=optional,

A couple of questions:
1. If the discovery functionality is truly optional, why log anything? Absence of optional functionality is by definition an un-exceptional event, so logging even a warning is going to unnecessarily alarm users.
2. How is ECF discovery supposed to be installed? Even if ECF repo is available at install time, p2 will not install bundles referenced optionally. ECF is not something that end-users will know to seek out on their own...
Are you sure these need to be optional dependencies?

(In reply to comment #7) > A couple of questions: > > 1. If the discovery functionality is truly optional, why log anything? Absence > of optional functionality is by definition an un-exceptional event, so logging > even a warning is going to unnecessarily alarm users.
It's optional in the sense that what I consider core connector functionality still works without it. We can consider alternatives if a warning in the log is causing confusion. Do you have suggestions?
> 2. How is ECF discovery supposed to be installed? Even if ECF repo is available > at install time, p2 will not install bundles referenced optionally. ECF is not > something that end-users will know to seek out on their own... > > Are you sure these need to be optional dependencies?
Yes, we have distributors that ship the Hudson connector but not ECF. We could consider splitting this out into a separate bundle and feature but since it was one class only we decided to make the dependency optional instead.

> It's optional in the sense that what I consider core connector functionality > still works without it. We can consider alternatives if a warning in the log > is causing confusion. Do you have suggestions?
I would recommend treating it as you would an addon. It's either there in UI or not. There should not be a notice in the log or elsewhere.
> Yes, we have distributors that ship the Hudson connector but not ECF. We could > consider splitting this out into a separate bundle and feature but since it was > one class only we decided to make the dependency optional instead.
The issue I have is that currently only distro builders can get this to work, and then only if they are aware of how this feature is structured and that you must add ECF manually. An end-user installing Mylyn would never be able to get this feature.
If making a few ECF bundles a hard dependency is really not an option (why would a distributor object to a few ECF bundles?), the only other usable option is to create a separate "Hudson Discovery" feature that would be available in Mylyn repository next to "Hudson Connector" feature for users to select.
Of course, Mylyn has way too many features showing in the repo already, making it overly difficult on users trying to install from the repo. A variation is to use hidden features. You'd have three. "Hudson Connector" would depend on "Hudson Connector Core" and "Hudson Discovery". Only "Hudson Connector" would be categorized/visible in Mylyn repo. The distributor that doesn't want ECF dependency can use "Hudson Connector Core" as part of the distro specification. The end-user going to Mylyn repo isn't aware of this complications.
Thanks for your input Konstantin. I have opened bug 406715 to suppress the logging as you suggested. I agree that it's not worth adding more features to handle this case.
